```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
```

```{r}
library(tidyverse)
NEM_Data <- read_csv("data/NEM_Data.csv")
View(NEM_Data)
```
```{r}
 New_NEM_Data <- NEM_Data %>%
 mutate(GridScale_PV = Grid_Scale_PV - Wind) %>%
 mutate(DistributedPV = Distributed_PV - Grid_Scale_PV) %>%
 mutate(Hydro_New = Hydro - Distributed_PV) %>%
 mutate(Total = Wind + GridScale_PV + DistributedPV + Hydro_New) %>% 
  select(Year, Wind, GridScale_PV, DistributedPV, Hydro_New, Total)
```

```{r}
New_NEM_Data %>% 
  rename(Grid_Scale_PV = GridScale_PV) %>%
  rename(Distributed_PV = DistributedPV) %>%
  rename(Hydro = Hydro_New)
```

```{r}
New_NEM_Data |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = Wind:Total,
    names_to = "energy",
    values_to = "values") %>%
ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = values, fill = energy)) +
geom_bar(position = "dodge", stat = "identity")

```

## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
